text: SERVES 6

500g red cabbage, finely shredded 2 tablespoons red wine vinegar a little butter or olive oil for frying 1 large red onion, finely chopped 3 sticks of celery, finely chopped 1.5 teaspoons caraway seeds 2 apples (Coxes are my choice), cored and cut into chunks 1.5 litres vegetable stock 2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar 2 teaspoons honey or agave 50g walnuts, crumbled a small bunch of dill, leaves chopped, with some fronds
reserved for garnishing
TO SERVE 4 tablespoons oat créme fraiche, soured cream or thick Greek
ONE:
Winter red cabbage & apple soup

This is a cheerful, vibrant soup which ticks all the flavour boxes. It's a soup | make all year, as it’s both comforting in winter and vibrant enough to eat on a colder spring or summer day too (think borscht). Sweet red cabbage comes with a pickled edge, earthy caraway and freshness from a couple of apples. The crunch from buttery toasted walnuts, brightness from dill and some levelling creaminess from créme fraiche finish it off.
| use an oat créme fraiche here but a dairy version or some thick
yoghurt would work too for non-vegans.
First, put the cabbage into a bowl with a good pinch of salt and the red wine vinegar. Scrunch together in your hands, then put to one
side to pickle, while you start on the soup.
Melt a little butter or heat some oil in a lidded, heavy-based saucepan over a medium-low heat. Add the onion and celery and sweat until soft
translucent, stirring from time to time. It will take about 15 minutes.

Once the onions are soft and sweet, add the caraway seeds and stir for a minute. Turn the heat up a little and add the apples and three- quarters of the cabbage, then fry for a further 5 minutes until
cabbage begins to soften.
Add the stock, balsamic vinegar and honey or agave. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat, cover and simmer for 30 minutes. Uncover and
simmer for another 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, heat a frying pan and add some oil. Once it's really hot, add the remaining cabbage and cook until crisp. For the last couple
of minutes add the walnuts and half the dill.
Back to the soup. Stir in the rest of the dill and season to taste with salt and pepper. You can leave this as it is but | like to blitz it with a
hand-held blender to make a vibrant purple soup.
Ladle the soup into warmed bowls and top each serving with the fried
cabbage and walnuts, a spoonful of creme fraiche, soured cream or
yoghurt and some more dill if you like.
